page.title: List of political scandals in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} {{Inc-up|date=May 2018}} {{Dynamic list}} {{Political corruption sidebar}} {{Politics of the United Kingdom}} '''Political scandals in the United Kingdom''' are commonly referred to by the press and commentators as "''''sleaze'''". ==Sleaze== A number of [[political scandal]]s in the 1980s and 1990s created the impression of what was described in the [[British press]] as "sleaze": a perception that the then [[British Conservative Party|Conservative]] government was associated with [[political corruption]] and [[hypocrisy]]. This was revived in the late 1990s due to accounts of so-called "sleaze" by the Labour government. ==List of scandals== {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} ===1890s=== *Liberator Building Society scandal,{{cite web|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19140624.2.74|title= LIBERATOR BUILDING SOCIETY SCANDALS|publisher=PapersPast|accessdate=10 January 2013}} in which the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] MP [[Jabez Balfour]] was exposed as running several fraudulent companies to conceal financial losses. Balfour fled to Argentina, but was eventually arrested and imprisoned. ===1910s=== * [[Marconi scandal]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomsbury.com/us/the-marconi-scandal-9781448205851/|title= About The Marconi Scandal|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|accessdate=10 January 2013}} of [[insider trading]] by [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] Ministers including: ** [[Rufus Isaacs, 1st Marquess of Reading]], the Attorney General ** The [[Alexander Murray, 1st Baron Murray of Elibank|Master of Elibank, Lord Murray]], the Treasurer of the Liberal Party, ** [[David Lloyd George|David Lloyd George, 1st Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor]], the Chancellor of the Exchequer **[[Herbert Samuel, 1st Viscount Samuel]], Postmaster General; was falsely implicated. (1912) *[[Shell Crisis of 1915]], which led to the fall of [[H. H. Asquith]]'s [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] government during [[World War I]]. ===1920s=== *[[David Lloyd George|Lloyd George]] and the honours scandal.{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/345191/David-Lloyd-George/4259/Prime-minister|title= David Lloyd George|encyclopedia=Britannica|accessdate=10 January 2013}} Honours sold for large campaign contributions (1922) * [[Zinoviev Letter]] (1924) ===1930s=== * [[James Henry Thomas|Jimmy Thomas]] budget leak (1936){{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/guides/newsid_85000/85011.stm|title= Budget Leaks|publisher=BBC Democracy|accessdate=10 January 2013|date=7 August 2008}} ===1940s=== * [[Hugh Dalton]] budget leak (1947) * [[John Belcher (politician)|John Belcher]] corruptly influenced – led to [[Lynskey Tribunal]] ===1950s=== * [[Crichel Down]] and the resignation of [[Thomas Dugdale, 1st Baron Crathorne|Thomas Dugdale]] (1954) * [[Suez Crisis]] (1956){{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/modern/suez_01.shtml|title= The Suez Crisis|publisher=BBC History|accessdate=10 January 2013}} ===1960s=== * Soviet agent [[John Vassall]] working for Minister [[Tam Galbraith]] (1962) * [[Profumo affair]] (1963): Secretary of State for War [[John Profumo]] had an affair with prostitute [[Christine Keeler]] (to whom he had been introduced by pimp and drug-dealer [[Stephen Ward]]) who was having an affair with a Soviet spy at the same time.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2001/apr/10/past.derekbrown|title=1963: The Profumo scandal|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=6 February 2013|location=London|first=Derek|last=Brown|date=12 April 2001}} ===1970s=== * Corrupt architect [[John Poulson]] and links to Conservative Home Secretary [[Reginald Maudling]], Labour council leader [[T. Dan Smith]] and others (1972–1974): Maudling resigned, Smith sentenced to imprisonment. * [[George Patrick John Rushworth Jellicoe, 2nd Earl Jellicoe|Earl Jellicoe]] and [[Antony Lambton|Lord Lambton]] sex scandal (1973): Conservatives, junior defence minister Lambton is arrested for using prostitutes and Cabinet minister Jellicoe also confesses. * Labour MP [[John Stonehouse]]'s faked suicide (1974) * [[Harold Wilson]]'s [[1976 Prime Minister's Resignation Honours|Prime Minister's Resignation Honours]] (known satirically as the "Lavender List") gives honours to a number of wealthy businessmen whose principles were considered antipathetic to those held by the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] (May 1976) * [[Peter Jay (diplomat)|Peter Jay]]'s appointment as British Ambassador to the US by his father in law, the then [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Prime Minister]] [[James Callaghan]]. At the time Jay was a journalist with little diplomatic experience. (1976) *"Rinkagate": the [[Thorpe affair]]. Liberal Party leader [[Jeremy Thorpe]] was arrested and tried for allegedly paying a hitman to murder his lover, model Norman Scott, while walking his dog on Exmoor; the hitman only shot the dog, Rinka. Thorpe was forced to resign due to his clandestine gay affairs, but was acquitted of conspiracy to murder. ===1980s=== * [[Joseph Kagan, Baron Kagan]], earlier ennobled by the Labour Prime Minister [[Harold Wilson]]'s notorious [[Lavender List]] (1976), was convicted of [[fraud]] (1980) * [[Cecil Parkinson]] affair with secretary [[Sara Keays]] resulting in their child, Flora Keays (1983) * [[Al Yamamah]] contract alleged to have been obtained by bribery (1985) * [[Westland affair]] (1986): The Defence Secretary, [[Michael Heseltine]] resigned from his Cabinet job in a disagreement with Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] over the Westland affair. Heseltine walked out of a meeting at Number 10 as his views on the future of the Westland helicopter company were being ignored at the time.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/january/9/newsid_2516000/2516187.stm|title=1986: Heseltine quits over Westland|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=9 January 1986}} * [[Jeffrey Archer]] and the prostitute allegations (1986), and his subsequent conviction for [[perjury]] (2001) * [[Edwina Currie]] resigns as a junior Health minister after claiming that millions of British [[Egg (food)|eggs]] were infected with [[salmonella]], stating that "most of [British] egg production" was infected (1988) * "[[Homes for votes]]" [[gerrymander]]ing scandal (1987–1989) * [[Bovine spongiform encephalopathy]] (1989) ===1990s=== * [[Arms-to-Iraq]] and the closely connected [[Project Babylon|Iraqi Supergun affair]] (1990) * [[David Mellor]] resignation after press disclosure of his affair with [[Antonia de Sancha]] and [[Gratis versus Libre|gratis]] holiday from a daughter of a [[Palestinian Liberation Organisation|PLO]] official (1992) * [[Squidgygate]], the covert leaking of a bugged phone call between the Princess of Wales and [[James Hewitt]], although the phrase originally referred to the exposure of the Princess's extramarital affair (1992) * [[Michael Mates]] gift of a watch ("Don't let the bastards grind you down") to [[Asil Nadir]] (1993) * [[Monklandsgate]] dominated the [[1994 Monklands East by-election]]. It mainly consisted of allegations of [[sectarian]] spending discrepancies between Protestant [[Airdrie, North Lanarkshire|Airdrie]] and Catholic [[Coatbridge]], fuelled by the fact that all 17 of the ruling [[Scottish Labour Party|Labour]] group were Roman Catholics. (1994) * ''[[Back to Basics (campaign)|Back to Basics]]'', a government policy slogan portrayed by opponents and the press as a morality campaign to compare it with a contemporaneous succession of sex scandals in [[John Major]]'s government which led to the resignation of [[Tim Yeo]] and the [[Malcolm Ian Sinclair, 20th Earl of Caithness|Earl of Caithness]], among others (1994) * [[Cash-for-questions affair]] involving [[Neil Hamilton (politician)|Neil Hamilton]], [[Tim Smith (UK politician)|Tim Smith]] and [[Mohamed Al-Fayed]] (1994) * [[Jonathan Aitken]] and the [[Hôtel Ritz Paris|Paris Ritz Hotel]] bill allegations, and his subsequent conviction for perjury after his failed libel action against ''[[The Guardian]]'', resulting in [[Jonathan Aitken|Aitken]] being only the third person to have to resign from the Privy Council in the 20th century. (1995) * [[Bernie Ecclestone]] was involved in a political scandal when it transpired he had given the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] a million pound donation – which raised eyebrows when the incoming Labour government changed its policy to allow Formula One to continue being sponsored by tobacco manufacturers. The Labour Party returned the donation when the scandal came to light. (1997) *[[Peter Mandelson]], Trade and Industry Secretary, resigned after failing to disclose £373,000 loan from [[Paymaster General]] [[Geoffrey Robinson]]. (1998) * [[Ron Davies (British politician)|Ron Davies]] resigned from the cabinet after being robbed by a man he met at [[Clapham Common]] and then lying about it (1998) * Conservative MP [[Jerry Hayes]] was "outed" as a homosexual by the ''[[News of the World]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.petertatchell.net/lgbt_rights/outing/outing_too_far/ |title=An Outing Too Far |year=1997 |first=Peter |last=Tatchell |authorlink=Peter Tatchell |accessdate=2020-02-02 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615231846/http://www.petertatchell.net/outing/outing%20too%20far.htm |archivedate=15 June 2011 }} with the headline "TORY MP 2-TIMED WIFE WITH UNDER-AGE GAY LOVER". Hayes had met [[Young Conservatives (UK)|Young Conservative]] Paul Stone at the 1991 Conservative conference and that same evening, "committed a lewd act which was in breach of the law at the time". Stone had been 18 at the time, whilst the legal age for homosexual sex in 1991 was 21.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/back-to-basics-of-vaudeville-1282058.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Peter | last=Popham | title=Back to basics of vaudeville | date=7 January 1997}} He had previously supported [[Section 28]] and other anti-gay legislation. (1997) ===2000s=== * [[Officegate]] (2001). [[Henry McLeish]], Labour [[First Minister of Scotland]], failed to refund the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] for income he had received from the sub-let of his [[constituency]] office in [[Glenrothes]] while still a Westminster MP. * [[Keith Vaz]], Peter Mandelson and the [[Hinduja brothers]]. Mandelson forced to resign for a second time due to misleading statements. (2001) * Jo Moore, within an hour of the [[September 11 attacks]], Moore sent an email to the press office of her department suggesting: "It's now a very good day to get out anything we want to bury. Councillors' expenses?" Although prior to the catastrophic collapse of the towers, the phrase "a good day to bury bad news" (not actually used by Moore) has since been used to refer to other instances of attempting to hide one item of news behind a more publicised issue. * In 2002, [[Edwina Currie]] revealed that she had had an affair, beginning in 1984, with [[John Major]] before he became [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]]. This was criticised as Major had frequently pushed his ''Back To Basics'' agenda (see above), which was taken by the media as a form of [[moral absolutism]]. * The [[Burrell affair]] – allegations about the behaviour of the [[British Royal Family]] and their servants with possible constitutional implications. (2002) * [[Ron Davies (Welsh politician)|Ron Davies]] stood down from the Welsh assembly following accusations of [[cottaging|illicit gay sex]]. Davies had claimed he had been [[badger]]-watching in the area. (2003){{cite news |first=Patrick |last=Wintour |title=Ron Davies ends political career |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/mar/10/uk.wales |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media Ltd. |date=10 March 2003 |accessdate=29 July 2009 |location=London}} * The apparent suicide of [[David Kelly (weapons expert)|Dr. David Kelly]] and the ''[[Hutton Inquiry]]''. On 17 July 2003, Kelly, an employee of the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]], apparently committed suicide after being misquoted by [[BBC]] journalist [[Andrew Gilligan]] as saying that [[Tony Blair]]'s [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] government had knowingly "sexed up" the "[[September Dossier]]", a report into [[Iraq and weapons of mass destruction]]. The government was cleared of wrongdoing, while the BBC was strongly criticised by the subsequent inquiry, leading to the resignation of the BBC's chairman and director-general. *In April 2004, [[Beverly Hughes]] was forced to resign as minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Counter Terrorism when it was shown that she had been informed of procedural improprieties concerning the granting of visas to certain categories of workers from Eastern Europe. She had earlier told the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] that if she had been aware of such facts she would have done something about it.{{cite news | title = Beverley Hughes | date = 16 October 2002 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/2173858.stm | doi = | accessdate =2 April 2007 | work=BBC News}} *In 2005, [[David McLetchie]], leader of the [[Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party]] was forced to resign after claiming the highest taxi expenses of any MSP.{{cite news |title=McLetchie resigns as Tory leader |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/4393622.stm |work=BBC News |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=31 October 2005 |accessdate=29 July 2009}} These included personal journeys, journeys related solely with his second job as a solicitor, and Conservative Party business, for example travel to Conservative conferences. Conservative backbench [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|MSP]] [[Brian Monteith]] had the [[whip (politics)|whip]] withdrawn for briefing against his leader to the ''[[Scotland on Sunday]]'' newspaper. *[[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] [[Home Affairs]] spokesman [[Mark Oaten]] resigned after it was revealed by the ''[[News of the World]]'' that he paid [[rentboy]]s to perform sexual acts on him.{{cite news |title=Oaten resigns over rent boy claim |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4635916.stm |work= BBC News |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=21 January 2006 |accessdate=29 July 2009}} *[[David Mills financial allegations]] (2006). [[Tessa Jowell]], Labour cabinet minister, was embroiled in a scandal about a property remortgage allegedly arranged to enable her husband, [[David Mills (lawyer)|David Mills]], to realise £350,000 from an off-shore hedge fund, money he allegedly received as a gift following testimony he had provided for [[Silvio Berlusconi]] in the 1990s.{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Owen |title=Q&A: Tessa Jowell and the Berlusconi affair |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article735579.ece |work=The Times|date= 27 February 2006 |accessdate=29 July 2009 |location=London}} Nicknamed by the press as "Jowellgate".{{cite news |first= Peter |last=Popham |author9= |title= Jowellgate: Italian judge will press charges over bribery allegations |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jowellgate-italian-judge-will-press-charges-over-bribery-allegations-468294.html |work=The Independent |publisher=Independent News and Media Limited |date=2 March 2006 |accessdate=29 July 2009 |location=London}} *[[Cash for Honours]] (2006). In March 2006 it emerged that the Labour Party had borrowed millions of pounds in 2005 to help fund their [[2005 United Kingdom general election|general election]] campaign. While not illegal, on 15 March the Treasurer of the party, [[Jack Dromey]] stated publicly that he had neither knowledge of nor involvement in these [[loan]]s and had only become aware when he read about it in the newspapers. A story was running at the time that Dr [[Chai Patel]] and others had been recommended for [[life peerage]]s after lending the Labour party money. He called on the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] to investigate the issue of political parties taking out loans from non-commercial sources.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4810670.stm|title=Labour loans to be investigated|work=BBC News|date=15 March 2006}}

Following revelations about Dr [[Chai Patel]] and others who were recommended for peerages after lending the Labour party money, the Treasurer of the party, [[Jack Dromey]] said he had not been involved and did not know the party had secretly borrowed millions of pounds in 2005. He called on the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] to investigate the issue of political parties taking out loans from non-commercial sources.

In November 2007, it emerged that more than £400,000 had been accepted by the Labour Party from one person through a series of third parties, causing the Electoral Commission to seek an explanation.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7111838.stm|title=Concern over secret Labour donor|work=BBC News|date=25 November 2007}} [[Peter Watt]] resigned as the General Secretary of the party the day after the story broke and was quoted as saying that he knew about the arrangement but had not appreciated that he had failed to comply with the reporting requirements.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7113255.stm|title=Labour boss quits over donations|work=BBC News|date=26 November 2007}} *On 24 January 2008, [[Peter Hain]] resigned his two cabinet posts ([[Secretary of State for Work and Pensions]] and [[Secretary of State for Wales]]) after the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] referred donations to his Deputy Leadership campaign to the police.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7206812.stm|title=Hain quits jobs 'to clear name'|work=BBC News|date=24 January 2007}} *[[Derek Conway]] (2008). The Conservative Party MP was found to have reclaimed salaries he had paid to his two sons who had in fact not carried out the work to the extent claimed. He was ordered to repay £16,918, suspended from the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] for 10 days and removed from the party whip.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7212990.stm|title=Tory MP Conway faces suspension|work=BBC News|date=28 January 2008|accessdate=28 January 2008}} *[[2009 cash for influence scandal|Cash for Influence]] (2009). Details of covertly recorded discussions with four [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] peers which their ability to influence legislation and the consultancy fees that they charged (including [[retainer agreement|retainer]] payments of up to £120,000) were published by ''[[The Sunday Times]]''. *[[United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal]] (2009). Widespread actual and alleged misuse of the permitted allowances and expenses claimed by Members of Parliament and attempts by MPs and peers to exempt themselves from Freedom of Information legislation. ===2010s=== ==== 2010 ==== * The [[Iris Robinson scandal]] in which [[First Minister of Northern Ireland]] [[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter Robinson]] stepped aside for six weeks in January 2010 following revelations of his wife's involvement in an extramarital affair, her attempted suicide, and allegations that he had failed to properly declare details of loans she had procured for her lover to develop a business venture. * The [[2010 cash for influence scandal]], in which undercover reporters for the ''[[Dispatches (TV series)|Dispatches]]'' television series posed as political [[Lobbying|lobbyists]] offering to pay Members of Parliament to influence policy. * On 29 May 2010 [[Chief Secretary to the Treasury]] [[David Laws]] resigned from the [[British Cabinet|Cabinet]] and was referred to the [[Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards]] after ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' newspaper published details of Laws claiming around £40,000 in expenses on a second home owned by a secret partner between 2004 and 2009, whilst House of Commons rules have prevented MPs from claiming second home expenses on properties owned by a partner since 2006. By resigning Laws became the shortest serving Minister in modern British political history with less than 18 days' service as a Cabinet Minister. ==== 2011 ==== * On 14 October 2011 [[Secretary of State for Defence]] [[Liam Fox]] resigned from the [[British Cabinet|Cabinet]] after he "mistakenly allowed the distinction between [his] personal interest and [his] government activities to become blurred" over his friendship with [[Adam Werrity]]. (He again served as a cabinet minister under Theresa May.) ==== 2012 ==== *[[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] 'cash for access' scandal involving [[Peter Cruddas]] and [[Sarah Southern]], March 2012. *In February 2012 Liberal Democrat MP [[Chris Huhne]] resigned from the Cabinet when he was charged with [[perverting the course of justice]] over a 2003 speeding case. His wife [[Vicky Pryce]] had claimed that she was driving the car, and accepted the licence penalty points on his behalf so that he could avoid being banned from driving. Huhne plead guilty at his trial, resigned as a member of parliament, and he and Pryce were sentenced to eight months in prison for [[perverting the course of justice]].{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21737627 |title = Huhne and Pryce sent to prison|work = BBC News|date = 11 March 2013}} * In April 2012, [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] MP and culture secretary [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]] came under pressure to resign as a result of his closeness to [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s media empire and alleged corruption in dealing with Murdoch's bid for News Corporation's takeover of [[Sky UK|BSkyB]]. * In October 2012, [[Andrew Mitchell]] resigned from his post as [[Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasury|Chief Whip]] following allegations made about his conduct during an altercation with police at Downing Street on 19 September, the incident becoming known as "[[plebgate]]".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2012/dec/19/andrew-mitchell-row-timeline |title=Andrew Mitchell row – timeline |last=Booth |first=Robert |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=19 December 2012 |access-date=2 February 2020}} ==== 2013 ==== * In the [[2013 Labour Party Falkirk candidate selection]], which began following the announcement that the incumbent MP [[Eric Joyce]] was to step down at the [[2015 United Kingdom general election|2015 general election]], allegations were made on the significant infiltration of the selection process by the [[Unite the Union|Unite]] trade union, currently the Labour Party's largest financial backer.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-23192888|title=Labour refers Falkirk row to police|date=2013-07-05|access-date=2019-07-10|language=en-GB}} ==== 2014 ==== * In April 2014 [[Maria Miller]], the [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport|Culture Secretary]], resigned following pressure relating to the results of an investigation into her past expenses claims.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-26902549 |title=Maria Miller row: Cameron faces questions, Labour says |work=BBC News |date=5 April 2014 |access-date=6 April 2014}} ==== 2015 ==== * In September 2015, [[Lord Ashcroft]] published a biography of [[David Cameron]], which suggested that the then Prime Minister took drugs regularly and performed an "outrageous initiation ceremony" which involved inserting "a private part of his anatomy" into the mouth of a dead pig during his time in university. This became known as "[[piggate]]".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/david-cameron/11880588/A-pig-some-drugs-and-a-disappointed-billionaire-the-life-of-David-Cameron.html |title=A pig, some drugs and a disappointed billionaire: the life of David Cameron |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |first=James |last=Kirkup |date=21 September 2015 |access-date=21 September 2015}} It also led to questions about the Prime Minister's honesty with party donors' known tax statuses as Lord Ashcroft suggested he had openly discussed his [[non-domiciled]] status with him in 2009, earlier than previously thought.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/sep/21/david-cameron-pig-head-lord-ashcroft-unofficial-biography-drug-taking-claims|title=Cameron biography: Ashcroft makes new debauchery claims about student days|last=Beijing|first=Rowena Mason Tom Phillips in|date=2015-09-21|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-07-10|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} ==== 2016 ==== * On 6 July 2016, the [[Iraq Inquiry]] (also known as the Chilcot Inquiry) was published. It described several questions about the grounds upon which the Blair government had allied itself with the US in invading Iraq in 2003.{{Cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/chilcot-report-published-iraq-war-inquiry-what-happens-next-tony-blair-george-bush-a7124521.html|title=What happens next now the Chilcot report has been published?|date=2016-07-07|website=The Independent|language=en|access-date=2019-07-10}} ==== 2017 ==== * In 2017 the [[Contaminated blood scandal in the United Kingdom|contaminated blood scandal]], in which many haemophiliacs died from infected Factor medicine, hit the headlines and Parliament with allegations of a "industrial scale" criminal cover-up.{{cite news|title=NHS blood scandal a 'criminal cover-up'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39713396|work=BBC News|date=26 April 2017}} MP Ken Clarke retracted remarks from his autobiography{{cite news|last1=Harpin|first1=Lee|title=Victims of contaminated blood scandal weren't given Tory compensation|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/victims-contaminated-blood-scandal-werent-10854692|work=Daily Mirror|date=22 July 2017}} relating to the scandal and a public inquiry is now underway. * The [[Renewable Heat Incentive scandal]] in Northern Ireland, in which [[Arlene Foster]] set up a green energy scheme but failed to introduce cost controls, creating [[perverse incentive]]s which eventually led to a £480m bill to the Northern Ireland budget. There were allegations that members of the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] attempted to postpone the closure of the scheme, which gave way to a spike in applications and causing the public purse millions of pounds. In January 2017, the scandal caused the resignation of the [[deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland|deputy First Minister]], [[Martin McGuinness]], after Foster refused to stand aside as [[First Minister of Northern Ireland|First Minister]] pending an investigation, collapsing the [[Executive Office of Northern Ireland|Executive Office]] and triggering an [[2017 Northern Ireland Assembly election|early election of the Northern Ireland Assembly]]. The resulting political rifts meant the Assembly did not meet again until 2020. * The [[2017 Westminster sexual scandals]] in which a number of MPs, MSPs, AMs, and other political figures were accused of sexual harassment and assault.{{Cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/sex-pest-scandal-engulfing-westminster-worse-than-expenses-11112503|title=Sex pest scandal engulfing Westminster 'worse than expenses'|website=Sky News|language=en|access-date=2019-07-10}} ==== 2018 ==== * The 2018 [[Windrush scandal]], involving members of the [[Windrush generation]] being wrongly detained, deported, or threatened with deportation which caused the resignation of then [[Home Secretary]], [[Amber Rudd]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2019/jun/16/windrush-scandal-the-long-betrayal-archived-documents-david-olusoga|title=Windrush: archived documents show the long betrayal|last=Olusoga|first=David|date=2019-06-16|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-07-10|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} *[[Jeremy Hunt]] property scandal – In April 2018, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that Hunt breached anti-money laundering legislation by failing to declare his 50% interest in a property firm. ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that Hunt was able to buy seven luxury flats at Alexandra Wharf, Southampton, with the help of a bulk discount from property developer and Conservative donor Nicholas James Roach.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/apr/18/jeremy-hunt-investigated-breach-money-laundering-rules-luxury-flats|title=Jeremy Hunt got 'bulk discount' on seven flats from Tory donor|last=Davies|first=Rob|last2=Syal|first2=Rajeev|date=April 18, 2018|website=The Guardian|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/04/12/exclusive-jeremy-hunt-admits-breaking-governments-rules-company/|title=Exclusive: Jeremy Hunt admits breaking Government's own rules over company he used to buy seven flats|last=Mikhailova|first=Anna|date=April 12, 2018|website=The Telegraph|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 15, 2019}} * Several links between [[Cambridge Analytica]] and high-profile donors to both the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] and the [[Leave.EU]] campaign.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/04/cambridge-analytics-data-brexit-trump|title=Watchdog to launch inquiry into misuse of data in politics|last=Doward|first=Jamie|date=2017-03-04|work=The Observer|access-date=2019-07-10|last2=Cadwalladr|first2=Carole|language=en-GB|issn=0029-7712|last3=Gibbs|first3=Alice}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/cambridge-analytica-bragged-we-have-vast-data-for-brexit-vote-a3797441.html|title=EXCLUSIVE Cambridge Analytica bragged: We have vast data for Brexit vote|date=2018-03-23|website=Evening Standard|language=en|access-date=2019-07-10}} * [[Andrew Griffiths (politician)|Andrew Griffiths]], Tory MP for Burton and Uttoxeter, resigned in July 2018 as Minister for Small Business and suspended for sending 2,000 texts, many of a violent and sexual nature, to two constituents in little over three weeks. This happened a couple of months after his wife gave birth to their first child. Griffiths was subsequently found to have a track record of misogynistic behavior and bullying. *In December 2018 Labour MP [[Fiona Onasanya]] was convicted of [[perverting the course of justice]] for lying to police to avoid a speeding fine. She was expelled from her party and in January 2019 she was imprisoned for three months. Onasanya refused to resign as an MP, making her the first sitting MP to be imprisoned in 28 years.{{cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mp-fiona-onasanya-is-jailed-for-three-months-but-keeps-her-job-kfjjrktgs|title=Disgraced MP Fiona Onasanya will be paid salary in prison|first=Will|last=Humphries|date=30 January 2019|publisher=|newspaper=The Times}} She was subsequently [[Recall of MPs Act 2015|recalled by petition]], the first MP to be removed by this process since it was introduced in 2015. ==See also== * [[List of British politicians who have crossed the floor]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Political Scandals In The United Kingdom}} [[Category:Political scandals in the United Kingdom| ]] [[Category:Lists of political scandals by country|United Kingdom]] [[Category:United Kingdom politics-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of events in the United Kingdom|Political scandals]]
